HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 6, 1925

THE AFTERMATH
The midyear ex=inations have come and gone, taking with them
a heavy toll. To those who have been dropped we can only wish reinstatement, or success in other lines. To those fortunate ones who
remain, tr,
;n particular, we can give more useful advice.
Much can be learned from the examinations, from failure as well as
success. The majority of new students during their first half year of
college work more or less in the dark. The midyears have, or should
have, cleared up many 'doubtful points.
Those who have passed all their courses have gained confidence in
learning that examinations are not insurmountable obstacles, but for the
most part fair tests of one's general knowledge of a course. The students who have failed one or two courses should learn the more useful
lesson of realizing the seriousness Of college work; and of not looking
at the absence of daily work, such as that required in preparatory school,
as an opportunity to loaf through the year. They should learn how to
study, and realize that one week of violent cramming is worth nothing
in comparison to steady preparation and note-taking throughout the
course.
A little celebration and relaxation after the strain of the midyear's
is quite natural and in fact necessary, but the danger lies in over indulgence and allowing class work to slide from week to week. Now is the
time to begin to work, for soon the rush of spring activities and an epidemic of spring fever will make study more difficult. All the men who
remain, from those oil the most ragged edge to those who were the most
successful, should profit by the lessons learned in the last two weeks,
and remember that the finals will come just as inevitably as did the midyears.

THE SPIRIT REMAINS
With the lifting of regulations, the "frosh" is no longer distinguished
from the presumably wiser upper-classmen. We congratulate them on
their release from the petty burden of cap, button, and the rest. However, it is our earnest hope that the joy of the freshmen in their newfound freedom will limit itself to the usual appalling array of glaring
socks and neckties, rather than in the forgetting of the valuable lessons
taught by the regulations.
The newly emancipated freshman is still on the lowest rung of the
collegiate ladder. If he fails to realize this even more than he did during
the hectic "paddle-swinging" days of the early fall, he has missed the
spirit and purpose of the regulations. The letter of tine rules has been
removed, but the spirit remains. There is no longer a system of game
tags, but there are still games to be supported; no more yells to be learned,
but there are still Hopkins teams to be cheered; no more compulsory
speaking on the campus, but the spirit of friendship should still prevail.
The basic spirit of the regulations is to make the freshman a better
Hopkins man and the "frosh" should "carry on" even more willingly, although the regulations have been lifted.

MYSTERIOUS TRACKS DRAW INTEREST
OF CAMPUS SHERLOCK HOLMES
Starting mysteriously in front
of the main entrance of Gilman
Hall, running down the steps, the
length of the quadrangle, over the
slope, across the bowl and into
Charles street are two tracks of
automobile tires engraved in the
fast disappearing snow.
Students on their way to school
for the first day of the second semester last Wednesday were astonished at the peculiar route
taken by the wandering motorists.
Many followed the tracks up to
where they started on the steps
of Gilman Hall.• Some looked inquiringly at each other while others winked knowingly.
Campus sleuths have deduced
the fact that the tracks were laid
on Tuesday night, the evening of
the last day of the exam period.
This fact disclosed a motive for
the deed. Working on the size
and depth of the tread the engi-

neer detectives figured out the
weight of the machine and finally
came to the conclusion, through
the process of elimination, that
the vehicle in the case must have
been a flivver.
It is conjectured that the driver
drove up on the steps of Gilman
I-Tall, turned around and headed
in a straight line toward Charles
street at no slow speed.
A rumor has arisen,at the Barn
which has it that a certain senior
received a "10" in an examination
on one of his courses of which he
was doubtful, and wished to celebrate in a unique manner. This
senior, having set what is his ideal
example for the other undergraduates, is now boasting of having
accomplished something that no
one else in the University ever
did, and at the same time having
celebrated his victory over
studies.

Extensive and eventful is the
program of the Homewood Playshop arranged for the next half
year. Like everything else, the
activities' of the Playshop have
suffered a partial eclipse during
the past few weeks because of interference by the inevitable midyear exams, but Dr. Small heralds
a busy season for the rest of the
year.
A major event of the program
is the Valentine Dance to be held
February 14th. All Hopkins students are invited to this much
looked forward to affair. Tickets
will not be sold at the door. They
must be obtained before the night
of the dance.
"Play-Tea" on February 22

Commemoration Day, Feb.
22nd, is the next important event
on the schedule. On this date, one
of the entertaining "Play-teas"
will be given in the Campus Theater in the afternoon for the faculty and students. A feature of
the tea will be the one-act play
"Washington's First Defeat,"
which is to be put on twice during the course of the afternoon,
from 3:00 to 5 :30. There will be
no charge for admission to this
tea.
Following the custom of past
years a Shop-night program will
be presented on February 28th.
Two original one-act plays will be
presented and will be followed by
dancing. Members of the Playshop will be admitted by card; a
charge of $.75 will be made for
non-members.
The March public bill, to begin
March 12th, is .also being prepared
and will consist of thre one-act
plays to be announced later.
All students who wish to co-operate in any way with these activities are asked to speak to Dr.
Small.

Belair is a quiet town. A peaceful
air of repose, of colonial quiet hovers over the sleeping village. A man
with insomnia can sleep in Belair.
Tonight Belair loses its olden
charm; rank modernism will invade
the place. And modernism will be
welcomed with open arms. Belair
is hospitable, and it has an eye
open, in spite of its seeming somnolence, for its own interests. One
year ago Belair was invaded with
the aforementioned modernism, and
it liked the new idea. Like wine to
its aged bones, like nectar to poor
humans, was this modern spirit.
Then Belair awoke, had one riotous
night of fun—and then the Johns
Hopkins Musical Club left town.
Tonight the air will again be rent
with the strains of college boys singing in close harmony, with the
plunking of collegiate banjos, and,
most modern of all, with the nerve
tacking tooting of the Blue Jay
Orchestra. For tonight, after a
year's absence, and a year's quietude
for Belair, the Hopkins Musical
Club will visit the Harford County
Metropolis.

THE AFTERMATH
The midyear ex=inations have come and gone, taking with them
a heavy toll. To those who have been dropped we can only wish reinstatement, or success in other lines. To those fortunate ones who
remain, tr,
;n particular, we can give more useful advice.
Much can be learned from the examinations, from failure as well as
success. The majority of new students during their first half year of
college work more or less in the dark. The midyears have, or should
have, cleared up many 'doubtful points.
Those who have passed all their courses have gained confidence in
learning that examinations are not insurmountable obstacles, but for the
most part fair tests of one's general knowledge of a course. The students who have failed one or two courses should learn the more useful
lesson of realizing the seriousness Of college work; and of not looking
at the absence of daily work, such as that required in preparatory school,
as an opportunity to loaf through the year. They should learn how to
study, and realize that one week of violent cramming is worth nothing
in comparison to steady preparation and note-taking throughout the
course.
A little celebration and relaxation after the strain of the midyear's
is quite natural and in fact necessary, but the danger lies in over indulgence and allowing class work to slide from week to week. Now is the
time to begin to work, for soon the rush of spring activities and an epidemic of spring fever will make study more difficult. All the men who
remain, from those oil the most ragged edge to those who were the most
successful, should profit by the lessons learned in the last two weeks,
and remember that the finals will come just as inevitably as did the midyears.

THE SPIRIT REMAINS
With the lifting of regulations, the "frosh" is no longer distinguished
from the presumably wiser upper-classmen. We congratulate them on
their release from the petty burden of cap, button, and the rest. However, it is our earnest hope that the joy of the freshmen in their newfound freedom will limit itself to the usual appalling array of glaring
socks and neckties, rather than in the forgetting of the valuable lessons
taught by the regulations.
The newly emancipated freshman is still on the lowest rung of the
collegiate ladder. If he fails to realize this even more than he did during
the hectic "paddle-swinging" days of the early fall, he has missed the
spirit and purpose of the regulations. The letter of tine rules has been
removed, but the spirit remains. There is no longer a system of game
tags, but there are still games to be supported; no more yells to be learned,
but there are still Hopkins teams to be cheered; no more compulsory
speaking on the campus, but the spirit of friendship should still prevail.
The basic spirit of the regulations is to make the freshman a better
Hopkins man and the "frosh" should "carry on" even more willingly, although the regulations have been lifted.

been a flivver.

drove up on the steps of Gilman
I-Tall, turned around and headed
in a straight line toward Charles
street at no slow speed.

accomplished something that no
one else in the University ever
did, and at the same time having
celebrated his victory over
studies.

night of fun—and then the Johns

most modern of all, with the nerve
tacking tooting of the Blue Jay
Orchestra. For tonight, after a
year's absence, and a year's quietude
for Belair, the Hopkins Musical
Club will visit the Harford County
Metropolis.
